DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Moscow Said To Offer Aid To Popular Forces
DOC.TEXT: State television said today that the Soviet Union had promised military aid to the popular forces that ousted Nicolae Ceausescu and fighting in fierce battles with elite police units of the ousted dictator. An announcer said without elaboration that the Soviet Embassy had pledged such aid but did not elaborate on whether it would be in the form of troops or equipment. In Moscow, Soviet media did not report such an offer. The announcement followed an appeal broadcast by the television from an unidentified army general, who urged Moscow to step in because ``terrorist units'' loyal to Ceausescu had sent reinforcements to the capital. Hundreds of people were killed in clashes in Bucharest between the army, which sided with the revolt against Ceausescu, and police forces that included Ceausescu's personal anti-terrorist squad. As dawn broke over Bucharest, anti-Ceausescu soldiers posted atop the TV building fought with pockets of loyalists in nearby apartment buildings in a firefight that lit up the early morning sky. The general's appeal came shortly after 6 a.m. as the anti-Ceausescu forces repulsed an attack on the television building, which the popular forces seized on Friday and from which they broadcast plans to hold free elections by April.
